children.text: This bill strengthens the accessibility regulations put forth in the 21st Century Communications and Video Accessibility Act of 2010. Standards for closed-captioning and audio description in television and online video platforms would be improved, and entities would have to ensure that users are easily able to choose closed-captioning settings on their devices. Video conferencing platforms would also have to update and improve their accessibility features. Similarly, 911 services would be required to provide equitable access for people with disabilities. This act grants the FTC authority to continue to update accessibility regulations as new technologies continue to emerge. children.text: The TLDR Act would require websites and apps to produce and make available to users a summary of their terms-of-service agreements. These summaries would have to be easily digestible by laypeople. Entities would also need to produce and share to their users a "graphic data flow diagram" of their data use. This act is an attempt to increase transparency surrounding usage of sensitive personal data (health information, biometric information, geolocation information, social security number, specific demographic information, audiovisuals, financial information, and browsing history). The summaries must include the following: - Types of sensitive data processed by the website or app - Description of the data used for the website/app's basic functions - Description of the data that will be used for future website/app development - Legal liabilities of the user - Terms-of-service archives - Directions for how a user can delete their sensitive data from the website/app or how they can stop sharing sensitive data - A record of all of the website/app's data breaches in the last three years - Total word count, page length, and approximate time it would take a user to read the entire terms-of-service agreement This will be under the authority of the Federal Trade Commission. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/4568/text?s=2&r=4&q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22trahan%22%5D%7D

children.text: This bill amends the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 to strengthen online protections for users under the age of 17. Operators of a website, online service, online application, mobile application, or connected device would no longer be allowed to target marketing towards minors and must implement mechanisms to allow parents and users to delete personal information. A Youth Privacy and Marketing Division at the Federal Trade Commission would be established to enforce the bill and provide a report to the House and Senate on how platforms are operating in accordance with the act. COPPA 2.0 was also introduced in the 117th Congress, but was not voted out of the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation. title: Fourth Amendment Restoration Act - H.R.237

children.text: Senators Marco Rubio and Angus King reintroduced the ANTI-SOCIAL CCP Act after introducing the bill for the first time in December for the 117th Congress. The act would prohibit transactions from social media companies operating in or under the influence of foreign adversaries, including China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, Cuba, and Venezuela. TikTok, ByteDance, and any other of their subsidiaries would be banned from operating the U.S. under this act. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/395/text?s=6&r=1&q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22privacy%22%5D%7D

title: Averting the National Threat of Internet Surveillance, Oppressive Censorship and Influence, and Algorithmic Learning by the Chinese Communist Party (ANTI-SOCIAL CCP) Act  - S. 347

children.text: This bill would require anyone who sells or distributes a mobile app to notify users before downloading or updating the app if they have been banned from federal devices. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) would be in charge of enforcing penalties, which could include a maximum civil penalty of $46,517 per violation. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/750

title: The Chinese-Owned Applications Using The Information of Our Nation (CAUTION) Act of 2023 - H.R. 750

children.text: This bill creates new consumer privacy protections in the financial sector by amending the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act to secure consumer financial data. Financial institutions including non-banks would have to inform consumers on how their data is being used and why the data is being collected, and have options for consumers to opt out of data collection not required for the use of the services. The bill includes a state pre-emption clause seeking to create a federal standard. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/1165?s=1&r=33

title: Data Privacy Act of 2023 - H.R. 1165

children.text: This resolution would help Congress focus on the safe and ethical development and deployment of AI that takes into consideration the privacy of Americans to ensure minimized risks. title: Expressing support for Congress to focus on artificial intelligence. - H.Res.66

children.text: This bill would designate January as "National Stalking Month" to promote awareness of all forms of stalking, including cyberstalking. Cyberstalking utilizes technology such as through phone calls, text messages, social media platforms, internet posts, emails, and electronic tracking to repeatedly surveil or give attention to a specific person, causing a reasonable person to feel fear.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-resolution/13?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22online+platform%22%5D%7D&s=9&r=1

title: A resolution raising awareness and encouraging the prevention of stalking by designating January 2023 as "National Stalking Awareness Month". - S.Res.13

children.text: This bill would mandate that the Comptroller General of the United State draft a report studying the impact of social media technology on youth mental health. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/410/text?s=1&r=19

title: Federal Social Media Research Act - S.410

children.text: This bill would require the secretary of commerce to create a process that prevents and prohibits transactions of information and use of communications technology products involving foreign adversaries. Foreign adversaries include China, Russia, Iran, North Korea, Cuba or Venezuela. The Secretary of Commerce would work with the Director of National Intelligence to draft a report for the public to understand what risks were posed with specified transactions. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/686/text

title: Restricting the Emergence of Security Threats that Risk Information and Communications Technology (RESTRICT) Act - S.686

children.text: This bill would require the National Institute of Justice to prepare a report to identify content patterns used by mass shooters through online platforms and social media. The report would be presented to Congress with the goal of identifying potential mass shooters earlier. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/563/text?s=5&r=3&q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22Facebook%22%5D%7D

title: Identifying Mass Shooters Act - H.R.563

children.text: This bill requires platforms to disclose the types of personal information used by their algorithms and how that information is used. It also requires platforms to disclose their content moderation practices and would form an interagency task force on algorithmic processes on online platforms to investigate discriminatory algorithmic processes.

children.text: This bill would create a new federal commission “to regulate digital platforms, including with respect to competition, transparency, privacy, and national security.” The commission would deal with issues related to AI, data privacy, powerful market positions, and the social harms of technology, like child abuse and cyberbullying. Sens. Warren and Graham published an op-ed in The New York Times on the bill, pushing to “rein in Big Tech.”Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/2597?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22to+amend+the+clayton%22%5D%7D&s=3&r=1

title: Digital Consumer Protection Commission Act of 2023 - S.259

children.text: This act requires that agencies be transparent with their use of "automated and augmented systems" for decision-making or public interactions. Agencies would also have to ensure that humans review any AI-generated decision that could affect people.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/1865/text

title: TAG Act - S.1865

children.text: This bill would prohibit online service providers from selling or disclosing individual-identifying data with any other person unless a contract is established with that individual. Providers would also be obligated to take steps to ensure that data disclosed to other entities is handled with confidentiality. The bill authorizes the Federal Trade Commission to take enforcement action with respect to breaches. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/744?s=1&r=11

title: Data Care Act  - S.744

children.text: This bill would mandate that the Center for Mental Health Services create a strategy that addresses the impacts of new technologies such as social media on children's mental health.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/3164?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22social+media%22%5D%7D&s=2&r=6

title: Protecting Young Minds Online Act - H.R.3164

children.text: This bill would establish an age verification process on social media platforms, enforcing a minimum age requirement of 16 years old. In order to access the platform, users would have to upload a government-issued identification to verify their name and age. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/419/text?s=1&r=18

title: Making Age-Verification Technology Uniform, Robust, and Effective Act (MATURE) Act - S.419

children.text: This act would require manufacturers to disclose when internet-connected devices contained cameras or microphones. The Senate companion bill, S. 90, was introduced by Sen. Ted Cruz (R-TX) and co-sponsored by Sen. Maria Cantwell (D-WA) in January 2023.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/538

title: Informing Consumers about Smart Devices Act  - H.R. 538

children.text: This legislation would clarify that the use of generative AI does not qualify for immunity under Section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934. This would allow companies to be sued for any harm done by generative AI models. children.text: This bill would require any person maintaining a website or selling an app to disclose to users if their data is being stored in China. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) would be in charge of administering penalties and enforcing this act. The bill was marked up in the House Energy and Commerce Subcommittee on Consumer Protection and Commerce.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/742

title: Telling Everyone the Location of Data Leaving the U.S. Act - H.R. 742

children.text: The bipartisan National AI Commission Act would establish a blue ribbon commission that would focus on AI, its risks, and potential regulatory structures. The commission would be composed of 20 members, half selected by Democrats and half by Republicans, who could use their experience in the fields of AI, industry, labor, and government to produce reports on AI regulationAccess the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/4223?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22ted+lieu%22%5D%7D&s=7&r=7

title: National AI Commission Act - H.R.4223

Particularly, the commission would regulate algorithmic processes and access to platforms, ensure competition, and protect consumers.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/1671/text?s=1&r=1&q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22technology%22%2C%22platform%22%5D%7D

title: Digital Platform Commission Act of 2023 - S.1671

children.text: This bill would protect the personally identifiable information of people moving to the US by amending the manifest disclosure process of the Tariff Act of 1930. Currently, U.S. Customs and Border Protection publicly releases manifest sheets documenting household goods imported to the US. The act would ensure that the publicly disclosed information no longer includes personally identifiable information like names, addresses, social security numbers, and passport numbers.Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/758?q=%7B%22search%22%3A%5B%22Moving+Americans+Privacy+Protection+Act%22%5D%7D&s=2&r=1

title: Moving Americans Privacy Protection Act - S.758

children.text: The STOP CSAM Act expands victim protection measures, directs tech companies to remove CSAM material, strengthens accountability and transparency measure for tech companies, and updates sentencing guidelines for online CSAM crimes. The Stop CSAM Act also states that civil lawsuits through the law could target tech companies for third party content, creating a Section 230 carveout. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/senate-bill/1199

title: STOP CSAM Act of 2023 - S. 1199

children.text: This act provides safer access to communications services to survivors of domestic violence, human trafficking, and related harms by requiring mobile service providers to allow survivors the ability to disconnect their service lines from their abusers' service line without charge. The Federal Communication Commission (FCC) would be in charge of adopting liability protection for providers and would work to expand federally subsidized services to survivors. Access the full legislation: https://www.congress.gov/bill/117th-congress/house-bill/7132

title: Safe Connections Act of 2022 - H.R.7132

children.text: This bill would require the Secretary of Homeland Security to create the National Strategy to Combat Illicit Recruitment Activity by Transnational Criminal Organizations on Social Media and Online Platforms. This strategy would aim to stop transnational criminal organizations from using social media and online services to recruit people in the United States into their criminal activities. title: Data Privacy Act of 2023 - H.R. 1165

children.text: This bill would direct The Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information to study accountability measures for AI systems. The Assistant Secretary would report their findings to the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House of Representatives and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate 18 months after the enactment of the Act. Specifically, they will be investigating the following: - The accountability measures already put in place for AI systems by communications networks - Why accountability measures are important in closing the United States' digital divide - The impact accountability measures will have on mitigating AI risks, such as the risks AI poses to cybersecurity - Barriers to the creation and implementation of AI accountability measures.
Access the full legislation:
